subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... To be fair, Anthony made (or implied) 2 points: (1) He believes you are a advocating a writing system very similar to TO. That is, you want a standardized
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:



>
> > - It freezes QS spelling so changes in pronunciation will never be
> > reflected in writing. One is just creating a new TO with letters of a
> > different shape which is a pointless exercise.
>
> Not at all. A huge number of old mergers (meet/meat, vain/vein) are
> disposed of, as well as gobs of pointless irregularities that have never
> meant anything to anybody.
>

To be fair, Anthony made (or implied) 2 points:

(1) He believes you are a advocating a writing system very similar to
TO. That is, you want a standardized (or somewhat standardized?) way of
spelling words. (I am inferring this from another post.) You also want
the writing system to be phonemical, not phonetical. You want the system
to be written in a standardized way that ignores dialect, so that
someone from America could read someone's writing from Australia and
understand it easily, unlike when someone from America heard someone
from Australia.

(2) He thinks such a new system would be "pointless exercise."

You addressed (2), but only addressed (1) implicitly. I am only pointing
this out so that because many on this mailing list seem to be dead set
against how you would have QS used. I am not saying I agree or disagree
(I still have to weigh the whole matter); I just want clarity on this
issue so later no one is surprised.

Paul
